abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The influence of genetic factors on the pharmacokinetics and clinical outcomes of rivaroxaban in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (NVAF) is poorly understood. This study aimed to explore the effects of <jats:italic>CYP3A4/5</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>ABCB1</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>ABCG2</jats:italic> gene polymorphisms on the trough concentrations and the bleeding risk of rivaroxaban in NVAF patients.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Patients and methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>This study is a prospective multicenter study. The patient's blood samples were collected to detect the steady-state trough concentrations of rivaroxaban and gene polymorphisms. We visited the patients regularly at month 1, 3, 6, and 12 to record bleeding events and medications.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>A total of 95 patients were enrolled in this study, and 9 gene loci were detected. For the dose-adjusted trough concentration ratio (C<jats:sub>trough</jats:sub>/D) of rivaroxaban, the homozygous mutant type was significantly lower than wild type at <jats:italic>ABCB1</jats:italic> rs4148738 locus (TT vs. CC, <jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 0.033), and the mutant type was significantly lower than the wild type at <jats:italic>ABCB1</jats:italic> rs4728709 locus (AA + GA vs. GG, <jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 0.008). <jats:italic>ABCB1</jats:italic> (rs1045642, rs1128503), <jats:italic>CYP3A4</jats:italic> (rs2242480, rs4646437), <jats:italic>CYP3A5</jats:italic> (rs776746), and <jats:italic>ABCG2</jats:italic> (rs2231137, rs2231142) gene polymorphisms had no significant effect on the C<jats:sub>trough</jats:sub>/D of rivaroxaban. For the bleeding events, we found that there were no significant differences among genotypes of all gene loci.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>This study found for the first time that <jats:italic>ABCB1</jats:italic> rs4148738 and rs4728709 gene polymorphisms had a significant impact on the C<jats:sub>trough</jats:sub>/D of rivaroxaban in NVAF patients. <jats:italic>CYP3A4/5</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>ABCB1</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>ABCG2</jats:italic> gene polymorphisms were not associated with the bleeding risk of rivaroxaban.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The studies involving human participants were reviewed and approved by Fujian Medical University Union Hospital Ethics Committee (Number: 2018YF005-02, date: 2018-3-14). Informed consent was obtained from all individual participants included in the study.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

title: The impact of ABCB1, CYP3A4/5 and ABCG2 gene polymorphisms on rivaroxaban trough concentrations and bleeding events in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation
